title: SHOCK PICS: Dad makes desperate plea to save sight as tumours ravage ENTIRE body
text:
HORROR: Shadot Hossain is desperate for help to save his sight 
Shadot Hossain, 47, is covered head to toe in the bubble-like growths. 
Thought to be suffering from the genetic condition Neurofibromatosis, Shadot will lose his sight if the overgrown tumours on his face are left to grow. 
The dad-of-three can’t wear clothes on his top half and struggles to feed himself because of the horror condition. Bubble woman Thursday, 6th March 2014 A WOMAN with a rare skin condition that causes bubble-like tumours to appear across her body has been forced to flee her village after her family disowned her in Indonesia. 1 / 10 SINAR SAKTI IMAGES/BARCROFT MEDIA 
He said: “It is very difficult to live with pain like this. I also suffer a lot with itching on the body and the neck. My body feels heavy." 
Shadot, from North Bangladesh, said he used to be handsome when he was younger but now even his 12-year-old son Abdullah is scared of his appearance. 
He said the comments and the staring hurts as much as the physical pain. 
"I cannot go outside because children are afraid of me. They call me 'Monster’, he said. 
"Nowadays Abdullah doesn't talk to me. I understand why he feels like that. I can't do anything for my son or family.” 
BARCROFT EXTREME: Medics say Shadot Hossain has the worst tumours they've seen “” 
Shadot used to work as a labourer but as his condition worsened he was forced to quit his job. 
Without a regular income he cannot afford medicine or further treatment. 
His wife Tajmohel Khatun, 39, has seen first hand the impact her husband's deteriorating condition — and lack of finances — has had on the family. 
She said: "He is not able to do anything alone now. We even need to help change his clothes and help with using the toilet. Shadot first noticed a tumour growing on his forehead when he was just 13 years old but it's only in the last five years that his condition has become so severe. 
Without medical intervention, doctors say Shadot is at risk of permanently going blind. 
Dr Mahmudul Hassan, who has been raising money for treatment, says he has never seen a patient with such extreme tumours. 
Thanks to his efforts, Shadot will go to the National Institute of Neuro-Sciences & Hospital in Dhaka for a full diagnosis and potential treatment. Related articles
